Posts.Content: eliza44  Hello, firstly sorry for you diagnosis. Personally, I would go back for the mastectomy on the side they offered and ask about a double (no harm in asking and explaining your fears) as I was told they usually do a double mastectomy for hereditary Breast Cancer or as reasons already mentioned.  I had a left side mastectomy in October on a lobular invasive tumour.  Which was 63mm and was hormonal after tests. I decided on reconstruction at the same time, so an implant in and had 2 sentinel nodes removed, then a lymph node clearance 3 weeks later. All went well, healed ok, a bit of lymphoedema (swelling.) but that’s more common in 2 ops. I’m now on chemo as a precaution I could have had radiotherapy and anti hormone tablets, but when my Dr advised chemo for more peace of mind as I’m only 48, I thought about it and wanted to throw everything at it. I think it would put your mind at rest if you went for the mastectomy. Wishing you all the very best, let us know how you get on x
Posts.Title: DOUBLE or SINGLE or not at all

Posts.Content: Hi All,  Looking into wearing nail varnish during chemo, (Fec-t treatment) but seem to be getting conflicting advice about whether to wear light or dark colours. Anyone point me in the right direction please.  Many Thanks x
Posts.Title: Confused... light or dark nail varnish during chemo?

Posts.Content: Thank you all for your advice. I’ve ordered some from a website especially for chemo patients, so it doesn’t dry out nails like ordinary varnish can.  What does everyone use for hydrating the nails, I’ve heard olive or almond oil x
Posts.Title: Confused... light or dark nail varnish during chemo?

Posts.Content: Thank you toxophilite Some articles were saying not to use dark varnish as you can’t see if there is any damage. Others say the darker the better due to uva, uvb and then lots about water based and nail strengthening etc, my head is spinning Sending hugs x x
Posts.Title: Confused... light or dark nail varnish during chemo?

Posts.Content: Hi All,  Im 2 treatments of EC down, 1 more to go then onto 3 of T which I think is Docetaxel. I’ve been very lucky so far only had chemo mouth and a bit of dry skin and slightly constipated!  Cold capping so have hair atm.  When I was diagnosed in October we only told hubbys mum and sister and my two closest friend, nobody else knew. I didn’t even tell my 4 children, 2 are older and live away from home. They knew I’d had a lump removed but not a mastectomy. We waited till after New Year to tell them. So many things going on, my mum was ill, we had youngests bday then Christmas and I only decided to go for chemo as a precaution just before Christmas. I could also give everybody a clear picture from diagnosis through treatments.  Have told a lot more ppl now as with chemo it’s pretty hard to hide. My friends have been great. Family are ok, my mum took it better than I expected but she had just had a biopsy for bowel cancer and was luckily clear but feels guilty now! She thinks it should be her, I understand because I felt like that when I was diagnosed I was just glad it wasn’t any of my kids. My Two younger kids are ok getting lots of support at school and we talk about it at home.  Hubby however has found it hard he doesn’t really want to talk about it, he was alright at the time of diagnosis as I think there was a goal, an aim to get through, the ops, the scans, the meetings with nurse and consultant but now he comes to chemo will me, but doesn’t have much to say at home.  I know how lucky I am with the ppl I class as my true friends and because I haven’t felt unwell as yet we have been able to go out for coffee or they are coming to see me when they can.  Coming here is very important for comfort, support and friendliness, someone is always here to help. I hope all you ladies will come here often x
Posts.Title: Protecting others

Posts.Content: Tray46 Hello, so sorry you find yourself here. I had a left side mastectomy with sentinel nodes removed, reconstruction with gel implant too, 62mm invasive lobular tumour (Hormone receptive.) Non sparing nipple, as the lump was close to the nipple. I’m 48. I also had to have a node clearance 3 weeks later. The waiting was, for me the worse bit, as silly as that sounds. As I waited for tests results from scans etc, not going to lie it was horrendous. I didn’t tell our children when I was first diagnosed in October, infact I waited till after New Year to tell them, all they knew was I’d had a lump removed, that was it! Not about the mastectomy or cancer. It doesn't necessarily mean bad news, my team meet on Fridays so could be the same at yours, they discuss everything then get you back, it’s easy to say Don’t Worry, but absolutely normal to do so though. I just tried to keep as busy as I could, my house had never been so clean! You are on an emotional rollercoaster so don’t beat yourself up about feeling emotional, I could go from laughing to crying in 0.5 seconds! Answer to moving on, hard one, do you have to move on yet? Should you? It’s all very early yet and I’m thinking your still reeling from diagnosis and surgery, I couldn’t even think clearly the first few months, it was only really in the New Year I came to terms with everything.  Get lots of support, from your breast care nurse, your gp, family etc. Let us know how you get on, wishing you well x
Posts.Title: DCIS & Masectomy

Posts.Content: MooCoo and Rosie,  I just started Docetaxel last Thursday and by Saturday was having horrendous bone pain especially in my legs. Saturday is also the day I start the 7 day course of injections I’ve been in bed since Sunday, the pain again last night was unbelievable, shooting pains and aching as well. Could stand it a couple of days but not till the injections stops!  Tina x x
Posts.Title: ***March 2019 Breast Cancer Chem Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hi WeCanDoThis  My experience is very similar, I had Docetaxel on the Thursday, like I’ve said started to feel a bit yuk over that weekend, i started to feel better Tuesday but I got a temp of 38 on the Wednesday I rang up and was asked to go to the hospital.  Bloods were ok, not neutropenic, but CRP 48, should be about 3-5, I had antibiotics through IV. Was allowed home at 5.30pm as temp was ok, but was told to go and the GP as they thought I might have some sort of infection. I also had out of hours phone me to see how I was. Couldnt get a GP appointment for Thursday but spoke to Nurse Practitioner and arranged to go for bloods on Friday, see what was going on. Friday had bloods done GP phoned later CRP was now 56, neuts had gone from 1.48 to 40 odd, gp spoke to oncol, who said it was high due to wbc injections and as long as I didn’t have a temp or breathing problems etc I should be fine to stay at home but call if anything changed over the last weekend.  Luckily I've felt ok. *touches wood*.  I’m seeing my oncologist on April 2nd, so will go armed with all info and side effects in the hope he might drop dose or something. Aliblue I took paracetamol and it did help with the bone pain. Thanks for replying x TheScriptFan Thank you. I did use a hot water bottle and it did help. I also have some heat pads because I use them on my arms on bloods day to try and draw the little blighters out. I was told I didn’t have to take my last injection of the 7 x x Hugs to all who need them.  Tina x x
Posts.Title: ***March 2019 Breast Cancer Chem Chat ***

Posts.Content: MooCoo Yes I did manage to walk up and down every hour or so and luckily started to feel better last night, Sod’s law lol. Only a few aches in the night just didn’t sleep last night at all! Really feeling the need for fresh air, but today my back is hurting, not sure if that’s the bone marrow doing it’s thing or just a bad back due to sitting down most of the time.  Hugs Tina x x
Posts.Title: ***March 2019 Breast Cancer Chem Chat ***

Posts.Content: Thank you MooCoo,  I meant to say the injections are for white blood count (bone marrow) so that causes pain and I know the Docetaxel does as well. I just don’t know what to do, should I be resting my legs in  bed or  up and walking about lol. I did do couple of laps of the bedroom earlier but got a cramp like painI really don’t want another night like the last 2!  Hugs x x
Posts.Title: ***March 2019 Breast Cancer Chem Chat ***

Posts.Content: NiceCuppa Thats the anti sickness tablet I’m on. It’s been brilliant for me, no sickness or even feeling sick.  I haven’t been given any antibiotics. Just have steroids 8 a day for 3 days starting day before chemo, it was 2 a day for 3 days after chemo on EC.  Tina x x
Posts.Title: ***March 2019 Breast Cancer Chem Chat ***

Posts.Content: MooCoo Yes I did manage to walk up and down every hour or so and luckily started to feel better last night, Sod’s law lol. Only a few aches in the night just didn’t sleep last night at all! Really feeling the need for fresh air, but today my back is hurting, not sure if that’s the bone marrow doing it’s thing or just a bad back due to sitting down most of the time.  Hugs Tina x x
Posts.Title: ***March 2019 Breast Cancer Chem Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hi WeCanDoThis  My experience is very similar, I had Docetaxel on the Thursday, like I’ve said started to feel a bit yuk over that weekend, i started to feel better Tuesday but I got a temp of 38 on the Wednesday I rang up and was asked to go to the hospital.  Bloods were ok, not neutropenic, but CRP 48, should be about 3-5, I had antibiotics through IV. Was allowed home at 5.30pm as temp was ok, but was told to go and the GP as they thought I might have some sort of infection. I also had out of hours phone me to see how I was. Couldnt get a GP appointment for Thursday but spoke to Nurse Practitioner and arranged to go for bloods on Friday, see what was going on. Friday had bloods done GP phoned later CRP was now 56, neuts had gone from 1.48 to 40 odd, gp spoke to oncol, who said it was high due to wbc injections and as long as I didn’t have a temp or breathing problems etc I should be fine to stay at home but call if anything changed over the last weekend.  Luckily I've felt ok. *touches wood*.  I’m seeing my oncologist on April 2nd, so will go armed with all info and side effects in the hope he might drop dose or something. Aliblue I took paracetamol and it did help with the bone pain. Thanks for replying x TheScriptFan Thank you. I did use a hot water bottle and it did help. I also have some heat pads because I use them on my arms on bloods day to try and draw the little blighters out. I was told I didn’t have to take my last injection of the 7 x x Hugs to all who need them.  Tina x x
Posts.Title: ***March 2019 Breast Cancer Chem Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hi All,  Im halfway now my 3 EC-T are done...yay! Going on to to Docetaxel tomorrow for 3 treatments. No really bad poorly side effects from EC-T.  I have a great anti sickness tablet so no sickness,  no fatigue, no aches from the wbc Filgrastim injections. No loss of appetite I’ve been very lucky. I take lactose to help with the bowels .  Only two bad sides cold cap hasn’t saved enough of my hair so it’s super thin and big bald patch at the back!  My Oncologist said at least 80% of ppl have total hair loss with Docetaxel so eyebrows and eyelashes too, so I’m prepared for that and the Filgrastim can causes hair loss and thinning too, so I’ve decided tomorrow I’m not going to bother with the cold cap. I have a nice wig I’m happy with.  I’ve taken 8 steroids tablets today and cried three times! Twice I have no idea why! I was told to take the steroids before lunchtime as I can suffer from insomnia.  Ive painted my nails, got a base coat and dark varnish from a cancer care website. I’ve been moisturising them too with a hand and nail cream. Any advice re the damaged veins? Unfortunately they can only use my right arm due to lymph node clearance on the left side. x x
Posts.Title: ***March 2019 Breast Cancer Chem Chat ***

Posts.Content: NiceCuppa Thats the anti sickness tablet I’m on. It’s been brilliant for me, no sickness or even feeling sick.  I haven’t been given any antibiotics. Just have steroids 8 a day for 3 days starting day before chemo, it was 2 a day for 3 days after chemo on EC.  Tina x x
Posts.Title: ***March 2019 Breast Cancer Chem Chat ***

Posts.Content: Pollydog  I was diagnosed with invasive lobular BC last Oct, 7 out of 21 of my lymph nodes were affected, so had clearance 3 weeks after mastectomy. My tumour was also over 5cm. I was asked about the Optima trial too. I really didn’t want chemo, so thought I’d just go ahead with the randomised bit of the trial and hopefully get Hormone Therapy...No, didn’t happen I was told I got chemo. I was told the computer picks ppl at random, the first lot have chemo, the second have their tumour scored, if score is over 50 those ppl get chemo as well and the others have just Anti Hormone Therapy . After I was told I got chemo I told the oncologist no thanks. However after another appointment with the oncologist after Christmas, I decided to go ahead with chemo and throw everything at this. I was told like you by my surgeon the tumour was gone, all the tissue was and that he had got it all and he was very confident that was it. I have 4 Children and a Stepson, whose girlfriend was expecting a baby. My eldest daughter wants to try for a baby within the next few yrs after getting married last year and my younger 2 were only 15 and 13 and all I could think was “What if I don’t do it”, I know my children need me and I would never have forgiven myself if I didn’t do this. I’m not sure they would either. I want to be here as long as possible. Has it been easy...No, but definitely bearable. I’ve lost hair, my eyelashes are going too, I’ve had nosebleeds, have to inject myself with bone marrow boosting meds, niggling little effects but I’m alive! Obviously ever case is different but I’m sure the oncologists do their best for each patient and they are the ones in the know.  Im 5 out of 6 chemos down now and im finding it harder since switching to Docetaxel but I don’t regret my decision, I ache, feel tired, have virtually no taste, bloating etc but I know when I look in the eyes of my children, I’m doing the right thing. Sending Hugs Tina x x
Posts.Title: Chemo or not to chemo invasive lobular cancer

Posts.Content: Dear Sophie,  You’re  welcome, happy to help if possible.  Emailing the nurse is a great idea, you need all the info you can get.  You need it to make an informed decision.   I definitely did not want chemo.. I told the oncologist I wasn’t having it. But whether it was because it was Christmas, (I love Christmas), I just thought about Christmas in the future with my kids  and with grandkids. I decided I would go for it, I did actually change my mind again but in the end after speaking to the oncologist again I got a start date for January .  Yes Optima is a blind trial so I don’t know which category I was in. The Dr doesn’t even know. He said he would always recommend chemo to someone so young! (I was 48) with it having spread to the lymph nodes.   I think taste loss is temporary yes, with my 1st 3 treatments it was only the first week after chemo. But some ppl don’t get this side effect.  If you want to private message me anytime it’s no problem. Thank you for your good wishes on my last Chemo, (2 weeks to go.)  Please keep in touch, Gentle hugs Tina x x
Posts.Title: Chemo or not to chemo invasive lobular cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Annecra, I was the same as you. I went to see my surgeon on the 15th Oct last yr and went for my op on the 20th as it was his rotation for weekend surgery, although I had a mastectomy not lumpectomy.  I had 21 nodes removed 3 weeks after my mastectomy but luckily I’ve not had a problem with my shoulder. Just do your exercises but listen to your body as well. If you feel tired rest, your body needs to heal which takes up a lot of energy. Best wishes to you x
Posts.Title: Post op advice

Posts.Content: Hi Pointer I’m 5 months post left side mastectomy and approx 4 months Lymph node clearance. I’m sorry I can’t offer advice on cording but I’m having this issue also. I had physio in generally but just due to weakness on left side, they have signed me off now, but I have suffered with Lymphoedema since the clearance but nobody will do anything till I finish chemo at the end of April. I have cording in my right arm due to chemo and worry I don’t actually have a ‘good’ arm. No bloods or IV’s can be done on the left side. So I worry about the cording in the right arm as they are really struggling to do the chemo bloods with numerous attempts to draw blood with little success.  Please let me know how you get on with your surgeon next week. Tina x x
Posts.Title: Issues after surgery

Posts.Content: Does look good.
Posts.Title: Hormone receptor-positive, HER2-negative breast cancer and Riboci...

Posts.Content: Love walking, (hence the name) I have tried to walk everyday while on chemoand I think it’s kept me sane! Well as sane as I can be.  My favourite walks are along the beach and we usually go in all weathers. So lucky to live by the sea. Tina x x
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Hi All, I finished my last chemo yesterday. Will still try and pop on when I can.  I haven’t got a date for radiotherapy yet, my oncologist said it would be three weeks after chemo but he had to ask me if he’d referred me! I have a meeting with a different oncologist so wether he is discussing this with me I’m not sure. I was lucky I tolerated EC really well but  Docetaxel a little less with pretty bad pain after the 1st one but better on 2nd, feel tired day 4/5 for a few days aches and pains and developed Hand, Foot Syndrome last time, Doc thinks it’s likely to happen again around day 10, just as I start to feel a better lol. Still positive vibes now, another hurdle over and moving forward. I’ve try to keep my energy levels up by walking 4/5 miles a day most days, was going great till the Docetaxel I’m too tired on the days as stated above Wishing everybody all the best for chemo and the mildest of SE’s Gentle Hugs Tina x
Posts.Title: ***April 2019 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat***

Posts.Content: Hi NiceCuppa,  I still haven’t heard about radiotherapy,  my oncologist told me it would start about 3 weeks after my last chemo, that was a week ago so I would have thought I’d heard something by now, however, I do have an appointment with another oncologist on 16th May, the letter just mentions a trial nothing about Radiotherapy, so I just don’t know. I think I might email my oncologist’s secretary to ask about this. Regarding hair, I basically don’t have much, I still wash it with the Simple range of shampoo and conditioner but I recently attended the Look Good, Feel Better session and received skincare products, make up and something for hair and scalp called Nioxin. I’m giving it a couple of months to see what happens first. I still have some eyebrows but would love my eyelashes to grow back ASAP. Im using Revitalash and Revitabrow products atm so fingers crossed. Hope your radiotherapy goes well, I guess I’ll be joining that thread next. Wishing you well Tina x
Posts.Title: ***April 2019 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat***

Posts.Content: Glad you are ok claire-h Hugs Tina x x
Posts.Title: ***April 2019 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat***

Posts.Content: HI Nic, It is very emotional, I was a wreck before my first chemo, I have my 6th/last just before Easter. Have hair loss, barely any taste left, some other minor effects, but no real poorly side effects.  Im sure your chemo team will give you info on your treatment including any other meds you might need.  They usually do your blood pressure, temp etc and will have checked your bloods if you had them done 48 hrs before. They will put you at ease, I shook all the way through my first chemo, it wasn’t the cold from the cap either, it’s the unknown I think.  I didn’t bother with the cap from 4th treatment on, too time consuming for me, I’m now in and out in less than 2 hrs.  I couldn’t colour my hair so wasn’t going to go out without my wig anyway lol. Please let us know how you get on, will be thinking about you tomorrow.  Hugs Tina x
Posts.Title: ***April 2019 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat***

Posts.Content: Hi Horsing Around,  It does feel good to be done with chemo, I think it’s because, for me it’s been 7 months since diagnosis so this seems like it’s all been worthwhile, the waiting for results, the ops, the chemo. Just radiotherapy to go. Hopefully regain hair and eyelashes along the way. My hands and feet are ok atm, but likely to flare up. My feet seemed worse quite a lot of skin peeled off and were burning last week, I did walk a lot though, I had to soak them in cool water most nights. Glad your hands have recovered, mine are the same now thankfully. Hugs Tina x x
Posts.Title: ***April 2019 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat***

Posts.Content: Hi Haysie  My hair was really thick, it didn’t really start to come out till about a week before the third chemo. It was gradual, then after third chemo on the way home, I felt my hair and it was a thick matted mess, I said to my hubby I bet it just falls it, I rinsed it and it just fell out in a clump, no idea what happened! Tina x x
Posts.Title: ***April 2019 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat***

Posts.Content: Hi Haysie,  I remember starting my first chemo at the beginning of January and thinking the end of April was so far away, however, it’s gone quite fast really. I planned little treats along the way and took it a day at the time, my walks really helped me in the early days even if it was freezing lol.  Thanks for your kind words, Hugs Tina x x
Posts.Title: ***April 2019 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat***

Posts.Content: I’m still here too, I have 2nd Docetaxel this Thursday (4th) and hopefully the last one towards the end of April. Struggled a bit more with the Docetaxel then EC. Seeing oncologist tomorrow so will see what happens there.  wigan59 so sorry you aren’t feeling well. I can’t answer your question, your body has been through a lot. It’s going to take time I guess to recover. I keep thinking what a nurse said to me about when you think about being pregnant, it takes 9 months to grow a baby, so it can take 9 months to recover, get back in shape etc. She said when having chemo for 6 months, think 6 months to recover and then double it lol, I know that doesn’t seem much of a consolation but I just think she means to give yourself time to heal,  it only physically but mentally too. Maybe speak to your GP or Macmillan unit if you have one close by. I’d also like to know about taste as I think my taste buds have left now....I did just read an article about a lady who is rediscovering her taste buds and she said food has never tasted so good I’m going to hang on to that.  Hope you start to feel better very soon.  Tina x x
Posts.Title: ***April 2019 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat***

Posts.Content: Hi Haysie Speak to the chemo nurses, my own opinion is it’s worth a try. They are the best ppl to advise you.  Yes I am in the Northwest Hugs Tina x x
Posts.Title: ***April 2019 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat***

Posts.Content: Hi Vicki, How thoughtful, what a lovely thing to do. I have found a lip balm invaluable as my lips are dry and the cold weather hasn’t helped. The ‘Simple’ range of products for hair care or anything very gentle, baby shampoo etc. Aveeno it very popular. Creams like E45. Bed socks, ginger biscuits, boiled seeets, a decent water bottle, magazines, puzzle books etc, neck pillow, notepad, nail and hand moisturiser I have a coconut one it’s 90% natural , it’s fab. I hope that helps   Best wishes Tina x
Posts.Title: Help for choosing gifts for friend having chemo.

Posts.Content: Hi Janet14 Sorry you find yourself here. You are definitely in the right place for help and support though. A nurse told me one way or another your body has to react to a traumatic situation, it has to come out somehow so your sickness and aches and pains could be a manifestation of that.  Please keep popping back on x
Posts.Title: The agony of waiting...

Posts.Content: Hi Lilly012 I went to the GP with what I thought was a cyst. At a referral to the Breast Care Unit on 2nd October I had a mammogram, ultrasound and biopsy.  The Dr spoke to me explaining he thought it was cancer. I had no other symptoms other than the lump. I’m 48, so not old enough for Mammograms.  On 15th October I was back to be told it was what he expected and as lump was quite large he wanted to do a mastectomy on the Saturday 20th, he explained we could wait and decide what we wanted to do, but I was of the mind if he could do the surgery in 5 days time I was going for it as opposed to waiting.  The waiting is horrendous. I had a chest ct, an abdominal ct and bone scan to see if it had spread anywhere else as it was in the lymph nodes (I had node clearance 3 weeks after the first op.) Luckily all scans etc were clear and my breast nurse told me the results over the phone as that’s what I wanted.   I didn’t tell my children till after Christmas. They knew about the lump,  that we thought it was a cyst so was removed but I wanted to have give them the whole story. Telling them everything in one go, and having a treatment plan in place, made it a bit easier on them, the younger ones are 15 and 13. I didn’t want them to be wondering and waiting for test results it was hard enough for us.  Wishing you all the best and I hope you get good news x
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer Symptoms

Posts.Content: Lilly012 You don’t sound selfish at all, I could only take it day by day.    We only found out I was going to be having chemo a couple of weeks before Christmas and it was my Daughters as well. I know exactly how you feel, I felt like I was going to ruin Christmas for everyone so I didn’t tell my mum or dad till after I’d told the kids, so they wouldn’t worry about them. Told kids a few days after New Year, my mum had been ill herself over Christmas and New year. I had my first chemo on 9th of January, my eldest daughter had come from Yorkshire and was with me when I told my mum a few days after my chemo.  Please keep in touch and let us know how you are getting on x
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer Symptoms

Posts.Content: Hi megzxxx I had my mastectomy October last yr and didn’t start my Chemo till January. I had lymph node clearance in November. Please try not to worry, at least after surgery the tumour is gone and the focus is a precaution.  I can’t help with the hospital you mentioned but I’m sure now your mum has the right diagnosis which is so important to get they can treat it correctly so much better than treating the wrong thing if that makes sense.  Hugs Tina x
Posts.Title: Worried Sick Delay in starting Chemo

Posts.Content: youngatheart,  Thank you for your reply. Yes I think this form just asked for biopsy report and anytime time spent in hospital as you get £100 a night as well.  Will wait and see.  Glad you got yours sorted.
Posts.Title: Well Women now Reassure cancer Insurance. Anyone had a claim in recently...

Posts.Content: Thanks for posting that NiceCuppa, I’m going to have a look as well. I’m also looking into Travel Insurance for Hoildays abroad,  Tina x
Posts.Title: Well Women now Reassure cancer Insurance. Anyone had a claim in recently...

Posts.Content: I’m in. Mrs50, I start on the 6th June for 3 weeks. I’ve had 4 months of chemo, so now about to start the last leg of treatment hopefully. Good Luck to all.
Posts.Title: **JUNE BREAST CANCER RADIOTHERAPY CHAT**

Posts.Content: I got confirmation today I get everything I was entitled too. Can’t actually believe it.
Posts.Title: Well Women now Reassure cancer Insurance. Anyone had a claim in recently...

Posts.Content: Hi TheScriptFan Sorry, Yes the insurance policy was something I took out years ago, well over a decade, I think it came about through my job at the time. It’s still worth looking into, I presume the premiums will be higher but I just think we insure everything else and maybe never claim but with the odds nowadays of cancer effecting us it’s got to be worth at least a bit of time researching x x
Posts.Title: Well Women now Reassure cancer Insurance. Anyone had a claim in recently...

Posts.Content: Hi All,  Just wondering if anyone has received a pay out recently. I had totally forgot I started the policy back in 2004. I was recently tidying our loft bedroom (empty since eldest DD went to Uni yrs ago) and moved away from home. Anyway found the policy, so put in a claim back in January, my forms are now with Reassure, they were waiting on the medical form from the Dr. My oncologists secretary phoned yesterday to say he’s filled it in and she was posting it yesterday.  Fingers crossed.  Tina x x
Posts.Title: Well Women now Reassure cancer Insurance. Anyone had a claim in recently...

Posts.Content: That’s great Aspen, I was really lucky as mine was due to run out in April this year as it was only a 15 year policy., So grateful now to that job or I wouldn’t had done it otherwise.  I didn’t even think to look if we have critical illness cover on our mortgage, I don’t think we do, but great idea to mention it here just incase, it’s useful for people to check their policy.
Posts.Title: Well Women now Reassure cancer Insurance. Anyone had a claim in recently...

Posts.Content: Hi there Sosad2019,  I was offered the infusion every six months. I’m pretty sure I’m not going to have them though. I’ve suffered with my jaw in the past so it’s not advised.
Posts.Title: Bone injections

Posts.Content: JayJerome Sorry only just seen this.  I presume you will know a bit more about your treatment now if you have been back to see your team. Have they got a plan in place? Are you having radiotherapy?  Yes my drains were because of mastectomy and nodes I think, because I had one drain after the lymph node clearance I had 21 lymph nodes removed 3 weeks after my mastectomy as is the first place cancer can spread too.  Let us know how you got on x
Posts.Title: I am new here, newly diagnosed with DCIS....

Posts.Content: Hi All,  I’ve been to an appointment with an oncologist today about my Radiotherapy, he listed best in order as Aloe Vera gel, e45 cream and then Aqueous cream.  I have e45 cream as I’ve been using that since my mastectomy and all through chemo, which has been ok but I’m thinking of getting some of the Aloe Vera gel to use as well as I think the gel might sooth more than the cream if skin does become red.  I’ve heard a lot of ppl say they used Avenno.
Posts.Title: Advice on which moisturiser to use during radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi JayJerome  So sorry to find yourself here. I had a mastectomy last October with 2 sentinel nodes removed. I was ill with the antibiotics but soon got anti sickness meds and was going ok.  I was in hospital two nights, felt tired for a few days but i wasn’t in pain. I’d say after the drains came out on day 14 I felt pretty much back to normal.  I got some front fastening pjs, some zip up hooded tops as it’s difficult to move the arm and your not suppose to lift your arm up so I was told to keep things at waist height, no reaching up in the kitchen cupboards for a couple of weeks. You don’t say if your having immediate reconstruction or not If you are, Do you have a compression bra? I was giving one of the sexy things at the hospital but bought some online in my preferred colours.  I still have some numbness in the breast area and loss of feeling under my arm but 3 weeks after my op I had node clearance so that’s probably due to that. The breast area healed quickly and I had no problem with it. I had nerve damage from my underarm to my elbow and still see a physio although this is so much better, no pain in my arm now.  I wish you well, anything else you want to know, send me a message, I’ll get back to you.  Hope everything goes well for you x
Posts.Title: I am new here, newly diagnosed with DCIS....

Posts.Content: Hi noswad1,  Firstly, So sorry you find yourself here.  Shock is I think, what most people feel. In fact when my surgeon gave me the news, he said,  “ You do understand what I’m saying, don’t you!”  I think everybody will tell you, waiting for the scans and then the results is really the worse bit, because it’s fear of the unknown. Please try not to worry, I know it’s far easier to say than to do, try to keep busy, arrange lunch with friends, do whatever you can to try to take your mind off it for a bit. My house has never been so clean as it was when I was waiting for results. I was the same as you, I thought it would have spread, you just can’t know till you get your results. Wishing you the best of luck, please let us know how you get on. Gentle Hugs x
Posts.Title: Grade 2 ER pos ductal

Posts.Content: Hi Leolady I’m having the EC part of Fec-t, I’m 2 down yay! One to go then 3 docetaxel.  At my 2nd bloods appointment it took 5 attempts to get blood as I have deep veins apparently.  The 2nd chemo was ok but I kept getting a pain in my hand and arm they kept saying the cannula was in perfectly but I was wondering if it was the cyclophosphamide as I’ve heard it can be hard on the veins, the nurse was very nice and did slow down pushing it through.  I am massaging it the arm and hand but thinking if my veins are that deep is it doing any good! So I too would appreciate any tips or suggestions. Wishing you well x
Posts.Title: Veins not cooing very well with chemo.
